title: Melampus bidentatus
text:
Melampus bidentatus <a href="common%20name">common name</a> the "common marsh snail", or "eastern melampus", is a <a href="species">species</a> of small, <a href="%3Awikt%3Aamphibious">amphibious</a> air-breathing snail, a <a href="pulmonate">pulmonate</a> <a href="gastropod">gastropod</a> <a href="mollusk">mollusk</a> in the family <a href="Ellobiidae">Ellobiidae</a>.
Description.
The maximum recorded <a href="gastropod%20shell">shell</a> length is 20 mm.
Habitat and distribution.
The minimum recorded depth for his species is 0 m; maximum recorded depth is 0 m. Like many others in the same family, this species of snail inhabits the <a href="high%20marsh">high marsh</a> zone of <a href="salt%20marsh">salt marsh</a>es, but it is also very common in the mud near oyster reefs. The native range of the snail is from the coast of <a href="Nova%20Scotia">Nova Scotia</a>, Canada, to the <a href="Texas">Texas</a> coast of the <a href="Gulf%20of%20Mexico">Gulf of Mexico</a>. However, it is likely that this distribution involves at least three cryptic species with distinct physiological optima.
Adults of "Melampus bidentatus" can survive in a terrestrial environment, but its <a href="larva">larva</a>e require an aquatic habitat in order to survive.
The diet of this species consists of the decayed shoots of smooth cordgrass, "<a href="Spartina%20alterniflora">Spartina alterniflora</a>".
